Ru content (wt.%) Surface area (m2 g−1) H2 consumption (mmolg−1) Surface species ratio Oα1/(Oα1 +Oα2 +Oβ) T1 T2 LBN – 20.5 1.12 2.46 0.66 Ru/LBN 0.48 23.2 5.18 2.42 0.85 Editor’s choice paper Catalytic activity of Ru/La1.6Ba0.4NiO4 perovskite-like catalyst for NO+CO reaction: Interaction between Ru and La1.6Ba0.4NiO4 Chao Sui Fulong Yuan Zhiping Zhang Dong Wang Xiaoyu Niu ⁎ Yujun Zhu ⁎ Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry (Heilongjiang University), Ministry of Education, School of Chemistry and Materials, Heilongjiang University, Harbin 150080, PR China Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry (Heilongjiang University) Ministry of Education, School of Chemistry and Materials Heilongjiang University Harbin 150080 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Ru/LBN exhibited good activity, reducibility, mobility of oxygen species, the amount and species of adsorbed CO and NO, which was associated with the strong interaction between Ru and LBN. In this paper, the activity of La1.6Ba0.4NiO4 (LBN) and Ru/La1.6Ba0.4NiO4 (Ru/LBN) perovskite-like catalysts was investigated for NO+CO reaction. Meanwhile, Ru/LBN exhibited much higher activity than LBN. The catalysts were fully characterized by means of XRD, elemental analysis, N2-physisorption, H2-TPR, XPS, O2-TPD, NO-TPD and CO-TPD. These results demonstrated that the excellent catalytic performance of Ru/LBN catalyst was associated with the strong interaction between Ru and LBN, leading to enhancing reducibility and mobility of oxygen species and increasing the amount of the surface adsorbed oxygen. In addition, the amount of adsorbed CO and NO increased largely for Ru/LBN. And Ru3+ species on the surface of Ru/LBN was considered as an effective active site for NO+CO reaction. In-situ DRIFTS was used for studying the relationship between catalytic activity and NO, CO adsorption ability, species and sites. The results indicated that the new active species were formed on the surface of Ru/LBN compared with LBN including inorganic carboxylate, monodentate carbonate, Ru-NO, bridged nitrate and nitrite. Keywords NO+CO reaction Ru La1.6Ba0.4NiO4 perovskite-like 1 Introduction NOx is a major air pollutant from automobile exhaust gas and industrial combustion of fossil fuels, causing environmentally harmful effects such as photochemical smog, acid rain, and haze formation [1]. Recently, the efficiency of internal combustion engine was noticed which was related to drive supply and pollutants emission (NO, CO). Therefore, the remove of NOx is an important subject to relieve environmental pressure. Among the technologies of NOx abatement reported, the reduction of NO by CO occurring over the three-way catalyst (TWC) has attracted much attention due to the simultaneous conversion of CO and NO, both of which are environmental pollutants [2]. Thus, researching an efficient catalyst for NO+CO reaction is meaningful to exhaust purification. Some non-noble metal oxides such as Cu-based catalysts [1–5] exhibited good activity for NO+CO reaction. For noble metal catalysts [6–10], it was found that the activity in the reaction of NO+CO followed the order: Ru, Rh>Ir>Pd>Pt [10]. And the Ru-based catalysts are well-known heterogeneous catalysts [11]. Moreover, Ru was proved as an active site for the chemisorption, activation and dissociation of small molecules such as NO, CO, NH3 and CH4 [12–15]. Li et al. reported that Ru-Mg-Al-O catalyst with good dispersion of Ru exhibited high NO storage ability [16]. Hornung et al. found the Ru/MgO catalyst had high activity and selectivity for NO decomposition [17]. Chen et al. found that the addition of Ru in Pt-Ru/Ba/Al2O3-Ce0.33Zr0.67O2 catalyst enhanced the NO storage capacity and promoted NO decomposition [18]. However, the catalytic activity of Ru-based catalyst was strongly related with the stabilization, size, distribution and agglomeration degree of Ru species. Komvolis et al. reported that the metallic Ru nanoparticle with size from 1nm to 3nm and high dispersion (70%) exhibited much higher catalytic activity and stability than larger Ru nanocrystal (10–80nm, far lower dispersion of 10%) for N2O decomposition [19]. Zhang et al. also identified that the incorporation of Ru in the hexaaluminate structure can stabilize Ru species and greatly enhance the N2O decomposition activity [20]. Thus, it is important and interesting issue how to retain the stabilization, small size and high dispersion of Ru species. Perovskite(-like) (ABO3, A2BO4) can be seen as interesting alternatives due to the low cost and good thermal stability even at above 1000°C [21]. Catalytic activity for NO decomposition into N2 has been focused over ABO3 and A2BO4 [21–26]. Zhu et al. have reviewed the preparation, characterizations and applications of perovskite oxides in heterogeneous catalysis [25]. Chen et al. found that the structural and textural propertie of LaMeO3 (Me=Mn, Fe, Co) perovskite could influence the NOx oxidation performance [26]. However, the temperature of NO+CO reaction for perovskite-type was high relatively [27,28]. Zhang reported that the temperature of NO conversion (50%) in the feed gas of 3000ppm NO for the LaCoO3 and LaMnO3 was about 375 and 415°C, respectively [27]. Zhu et al. showed the temperature of NO conversion (50%) over the La2CuO4 catalyst was higher than 500°C [28]. Thus, it is necessary to decrease the temperature of NO+CO reaction over perovskite-type catalyst based on its advantages. Nowadays, researchers found that noble metal-modified perovskite(-like) can stabilize the noble metal dispersion, which was due to the strong interaction between noble metal and perovskite(-like) [29–34]. Therefore, the perovskite(-like) catalysts modified with noble metal were studied based on their advantages. Zhang et al. [30] and Karita et al. [31] found the LaFe0.97Pd0.03O3 and Pd/La0.2Sr1.2MnO4 perovskite(-like) catalysts showed great catalytic activity for NO+CO reaction as a result of the interaction between Pd and perovskite(-like) oxide. Pt and perovskite (LaFeO3, La0.5Ce0.5MnO3, La0.7Sr0.2Ce0.1FeO3) also displayed a cooperative effect on the removal of NO [32–34], which exhibited a high NO conversion. In our previous work [35], it has also been found that the effect of different prepared method on the activity and stability of Ru supported on La1.6Sr0.4NiO4 perovskite-like catalysts was obvious for the decomposition of N2O. Thus, it is significant to study the interaction between Ru and perovskite-like to enhance the catalytic activity for NO+CO reaction. In our previous report, the La1.6Ba0.4NiO4 perovskite-like catalyst showed good redox and mobility of lattice oxygen in NO decomposition [23]. Ru could adsorb NO effectively, which was benefit to the reaction of NO and CO [36]. Based on the above descriptions, the catalyst that Ru supported on La1.6Ba0.4NiO4 perovskite-like was prepared for the reduction of NO with CO. The effects Ru addition on the catalytic activity of Ru/La1.6Ba0.4NiO4 were investigated by various characterizations and in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS). 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation La1.6Ba0.4NiO4 sample was prepared by sol-gel method described as the reference [35] which denoted as LBN. Ru/La1.6Ba0.4NiO4 (Ru/LBN) was prepared as follows: Firstly, RuCl3 ×solution (30mL, 5.00mmolL−1) was added into the solution of 40mL deionized water and 30mL ethylene glycol. And then LBN sample (3.00g) was added into the above solution under stirring at room temperature. After stirring for 24h, the mixture was filtered, and the obtained precipitate was washed with deionized water till no Cl− was tested by AgNO3 and dilute HNO3 solution. The precipitate was dried at 110°C overnight in an oven and calcined at 600°C for 2h under the mixture gas of 10 vol.% H2/N2 to obtain Ru/LBN. The nominal Ru content was 0.5wt%. 2.2 Catalyst characterization BET surface area was measured from the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms at −196°C using a Micromeritics Tristar II 3020 analyzer. The Ru content (wt.%) were determined by inductive coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) (Optima 7000 DV, Perkin Elmer). X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed by using a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ =1.5418Å) radiation (40kV, 40mA). The diffraction patterns were scanned in the 2θ range of 10–80° with the steps of 0.02°. XPS was made on AXIS ULTRA DLD X spectrometer using Al Kα radiation as the excitation source. In addition, detailed scans of the O1s, Ru3d, Ni2p and C1s regions were acquired for each sample. The temperature programmed reduction with H2 (H2-TPR), temperature programmed desorption of O2 (O2-TPD) and NO/CO (NO-TPD/CO-TPD) experiments were carried out by using the AutoChem tp5080 chemisorptions analyzer (Xianquan Tianjin, China). Typical experiments were performed as our described elsewhere [36–38]. NO-TPD-MS/CO-TPD-MS with MS as detector (QIC-20, Hiden, England) online analysis monitored the signals of m/z equal to 28 (N2), 44(N2O), 30 (NO), 46 (NO2), 32 (O2), 28 (CO) and 44 (CO2). In situ DRIFTS was recorded with a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer with in situ diffuse reflectance pool (Harrick) and high sensitivity MCT detector which cooled by liquid N2. Typical experimental method was described as the reference [38]. The DRIFTS was recorded by accumulating 64 scans with a resolution of 4cm−1. The DRIFTS was presented as obtained without smoothing. 2.3 Catalytic experiments The catalytic activity of LBN and Ru/LBN for NO+CO reaction was carried out in a conventional fixed-bed reactor with a 6 mm-diameter quartz glass tube. Gaseous mixtures of 0.5% NO (25mLmin−1) and 0.5% CO (25mLmin−1) diluted with He were fed to the catalyst bed, the total flow rate of the feed gas was 50mLmin−1. In each experiment, 0.100g of the catalyst (40–60mesh) without dilution was set in the reactor by using quartz wool. At each examined temperature, the reaction was kept for 60min before measuring. The concentration measurement of the reaction products and remaining NO, CO at the reactor outlet were performed by gas chromatography (SP3420A, Beifen, China) equipped with 5A molecular sieve and Porapak Q columns. The activity of NO+CO reaction was evaluated by the following equations: (1) N2 yield%=2[N2]out/[NO]in ×100% (2) N2O yield%=2[N2O]out/[NO]in ×100% (3) NO conversion%=([NO]in-[NO]out)/[NO]in ×100% (4) CO conversion%=([CO]in-[CO]out)/[CO]in ×100% where [NO]in and [CO]in refer to the inlet concentrations of NO and CO, respectively, [NO]out, [CO]out, [N2O]out and [N2]out refer to reactor outlet concentrations of NO, CO, N2O and N2, respectively. To further evaluate the catalytic activity, kinetic parameter for the NO conversion was calculated: (5) k = − V W × ln ( 1 − x ) Where k is the reaction rate constant (cm3 g−1 s−1), V is the total gas flow rate (cm3 s−1), W is the mass of catalyst, and x is the conversion of NO. The equation is based on the theory that the reaction is first-order [39]. 3 Results 3.1 Catalytic activity test Fig. 1 presents the catalytic activity over Ru/LBN and LBN. As shown in Fig. 1a, the Ru/LBN catalyst obviously enhanced NO conversion compared with the LBN catalyst. The NO conversion increased with the reaction temperature from 300°C to 500°C over Ru/LBN. However, LBN exhibited very low activity especially at the reaction temperature below 350°C, whose conversion of NO was hardly observed. When the temperature increased to 350°C, the conversion of NO reached about 65% for Ru/LBN, while the NO conversion was only about 5% over LBN. Furthermore, the conversion of NO for LBN and Ru/LBN increased to 42% and 92% at 450°C, respectively, correspondingly, 55% and 100% at 500°C. It was noticed that the NO conversion over Ru/LBN was obviously higher than that over LBN at every tested temperature. The trend of CO conversion was similar to that of NO conversion over both LBN and Ru/LBN catalysts as shown in Fig. 1b. The reaction rate constant k based on the Eq. (5) was calculated for the Ru/LBN and LBN catalysts and displayed in Fig. S1 in the Supplementary information. For the Ru/LBN catalyst, the reaction rate constant k was 8.5, 13.4 and 14.3cm3 g−1 s−1 at 350, 375 and 400°C, respectively, which illustrates an increasing trend with the change of temperature. For LBN catalyst, it exhibited much lower reaction rates, and the k was 0.28, 1.8, 4.6, 6.5 and 13.4cm3 g−1 s−1 at 350, 400, 450, 500 and 550°C, respectively. The catalytic activity increased with the reaction temperature from 300°C to 500°C over Ru/LBN, which should be attributed to the increase in the reaction rate constant. Fig. 1c and d exhibited the curves of N2 and N2O yield over the LBN and Ru/LBN catalysts. For LBN, the N2 and N2O yield were 22% and 20% at 450°C, respectively. At 500°C, they were 36% and 16%. When the temperature increased to 550°C, the N2 yield increased to 92% and N2O disappeared. For Ru/LBN catalyst, the N2 and N2O yield were 10% and 55% at 350°C, respectively. Meanwhile, the N2 yield increased from 10% to 94% and N2O was not observed at 500°C. It means that N2O is the primary product at low temperature and that N2 is the main product at high temperature. Moreover, the N2 and N2O yield of Ru/LBN is much higher than that of LBN. The effect of time-on-stream on activity was also tested over the Ru/LBN catalyst. Fig. S2 in the Supplementary information showed the NO conversion versus time-on-stream curves at 450°C. It can be seen that NO conversion was about 90% and did not decrease even after using 10h. The result indicates that the Ru/LBN catalyst can maintain stable activity during the evaluated time. 3.2 Characterization of the LBN and Ru/LBN Fig. 2 displayed the XRD patterns of the LBN and Ru/LBN catalysts. The peaks of LBN at 24.05, 28.08, 31.32, 32.74, 42.52, 43.66, 47.00, 53.48, 54.80, 55.58, 56.00, 57.59, 65.36, 68.28, 76.08, 77.39 and 78.18° were in good agreement with those of an La2NiO4 orthorhombic phase with perovskite-like structure (PDF 34-0314) [24], and other phases such as La2O3, NiO and BaCO3 were not observed [23]. For Ru/LBN, the XRD pattern was similar to LBN. Meanwhile, metallic Ru or RuOx species was not detected. It indicates that Ru is great dispersed on the surface of LBN catalyst. The main physicochemical properties of the LBN and Ru/LBN were summarized in Table 1 . The BET surface areas of LBN and Ru/LBN were 20.5 and 23.2m2 g−1, respectively. It can be seen that the BET surface area of Ru/LBN was slightly higher than that of LBN, which suggests surface structure of Ru/LBN may be changed due to the Ru addition. The chemical analysis (ICP-AES) results showed that the Ru content was 0.48wt% for the Ru/LBN catalyst, which was close to the theoretical content (0.50wt%). The H2-TPR of the LBN and Ru/LBN catalysts was carried out to examine their reducibility and the results were depicted in Fig. 3 . The hydrogen consumption was listed in Table 1. For LBN, the peak at 300–500°C was attributed to the reduction of Ni3+ to Ni2+ accompanying the reduction of chemical adsorptive oxygen [23,28,40,41]. The peak at 700°C was mainly ascribed to Ni2+ to Ni0 at high temperature region, which indicates the reducibility of lattice oxygen [23,41,42]. For Ru/LBN, the consecutive reduction peak in range of 200–500°C was ascribed to the reduction of the high oxidation state of Ru species (Ru3+ or Ru4+) and chemical adsorption oxygen accompanying the reduction of Ni3+. The peak located at around 600°C was mainly assigned to the reduction of the lattice oxygen, which indicates the reducibility of Ni2+ to Ni0 [23,41,42]. It was noteworthy that the reduction temperature of chemical adsorption oxygen was lower about 150°C than that of LBN catalyst. It suggests that the reducibility of catalyst increases after Ru addition. As listed in Table 1, the H2 consumption in range of 200–500°C (T1) was 5.18mmolg−1 for Ru/LBN catalyst, which was much higher than that of LBN catalyst (1.12mmolg−1, 250–500°C). If the valence state of the Ru species is +3, the H2 consumption of Ru species should be about 0.075mmolg−1 in theoretical calculation based Ru content. Obviously, it was far less than the H2 consumption the T1 peak (5.18mmolg−1). Thus, the result means that Ru/LBN possesses much greater amount of chemical adsorbed oxygen than that of LBN. Moreover, the reduction peak assigned to the lattice oxygen (T2) shifted from 675°C (LBN) to 600°C (Ru/LBN). The result indicates that the mobility of lattice oxygen is improved [28,43,44]. On the whole, the amount of chemical adsorbed oxygen and the mobility of lattice oxygen increase after Ru supporting on the LBN, which should be attributed to the strong interaction between Ru and LBN. The O2-TPD of LBN and Ru/LBN catalysts was tested and the curves were displayed in Fig. 4 . The peak at 300–450°C corresponded to the desorption of surface chemical adsorbed oxygen (α oxygen). The peak appeared in range of 450–650°C could be attributed to the desorption of the surface lattice oxygen (β oxygen). The peak appeared at above 650°C was assigned to the desorption of bulk lattice oxygen (γ oxygen) [23,25,42]. For the LBN catalyst, two desorption peaks observed at 400 and 575°C were assigned to α oxygen and β oxygen, respectively. The bulk lattice oxygen (γ oxygen) desorbed at above 700°C. For Ru/LBN, four peaks were given at 375, 550, 700 and 780°C, which were assigned to the desorption of α oxygen, β oxygen, γ1 oxygen and γ2 oxygen, respectively. Compared with the LBN catalyst, the desorption of γ oxygen shifted to the lower temperature. It suggests that the mobility of bulk lattice oxygen is enhanced, which is in agreement with the H2-TPR results. Two desorption peaks of bulk lattice oxygen were observed due to the interaction of Ru and LBN. Meanwhile, it was noticed that every area of the desorption peak over the Ru/LBN catalyst was much larger than that of LBN. It indicates that the amount of surface oxygen species increases and mobility of bulk lattice oxygen is improved after Ru supporting on LBN, which is also consistent with the H2-TPR results. NO-TPD curves of LBN and Ru/LBN were measured as presented in Fig. 5 . Desorption species of NO-TPD was tested by the mass spectrometry (Fig. 5b–d) and O2, N2, N2O, NO were tracked monitoring. In Fig. 5a, some desorption peaks could be observed with TCD signals in the range of 300–900°C for the LBN catalyst. Combined with MS signals in Fig. 5b and c, the peak at 300–450°C was attributed to the desorption of N2O molecule. Another peak at 450–700°C was assigned to the desorption of N2O and O2 molecules. The peak presented between 700 and 900°C was attributed to the desorption of N2O, N2 and O2. For Ru/LBN catalyst, four desorption peaks were clearly observed at 375, 560, 700 and 780°C, respectively, as shown in Fig. 5a. Combined with MS signals in Fig. 5b and d, the peak at 375°C was ascribed to the N2O desorption and the peaks at 560, 700 and 780°C were assigned to the desorption of N2O and N2. From the NO-TPD results of the Ru/LBN and LBN catalysts (Fig. 5a), the desorption peaks number of Ru/LBN was more than that of LBN. It suggests that there are more NO adsorption sites on the surface of Ru/LBN. Meanwhile, it is noteworthy that the desorption peak area of Ru/LBN was much larger than that of LBN (Fig. 5a). It means that the amount of NO adsorption increases obviously after the addition of Ru into LBN. Moreover, it can be seen that a large amount of N2O (Fig. 5d) were formed in the desorption process for the Ru/LBN catalyst. However, the amount of NO desorption was much less than that of N2O for the Ru/LBN catalyst. In addition, though the scale of ion current intensity was so much small (5E-10), the amount of N2O, N2 and NO desorption over LBN were still a little in Fig. 5c. Thus, it suggests that a large number of adsorbed NO molecules interact with active sites to form N2O, N2 and O2 rather than desorbing on the surface of Ru/LBN. CO-TPD curves of LBN and Ru/LBN were measured as given in Fig. 6 . The desorption species including O2, CO2 and CO were tracked by the mass spectrometry (Fig. 6b–d). In Fig. 6a, some desorption peaks could be observed in the range of 300–900°C for the LBN catalyst. Combined with Fig. 6b and c, the peak at 300–450°C was attributed to the CO2 desorption, and the peaks at 450–800°C were assigned to the desorption of CO2 and O2. And the peak at 800–900°C was attributed to the desorption of CO2, O2 and CO. For the Ru/LBN catalyst, four obvious desorption peaks were observed at 375, 560, 710 and 780°C. Compared with LBN (Fig. 6a), Ru/LBN exhibited much larger peak area for above four desorption peaks. It suggests that there are more CO adsorption sites on the surface of Ru/LBN catalyst. In addition, it can be seen that a large amount of CO2 was obtained from Ru/LBN (Fig. 6d) rather than LBN (Fig. 6c). Moreover, the amount of CO desorption over Ru/LBN was much larger than that of LBN from Fig. 6b, though the peak of CO desorption for the Ru/LBN catalyst was small. Therefore, the CO-TPD results indicate that much more CO can adsorb on the surface of Ru/LBN. Meanwhile, most of adsorbed CO is oxidized to CO2 with the increase in the desorption temperature in the CO-TPD process. On the whole, the Ru/LBN catalyst displays more adsorbed active sites than the LBN catalyst from the results of NO-TPD and CO-TPD. It is interesting that the shape and the number of the desorption peaks were similar for NO-TPD (Fig. 5a) and CO-TPD (Fig. 6a) profiles, which indicates that the adsorbed sites of NO may be same with those of CO. XPS of O1s for the LBN and Ru/LBN catalysts were measured in order to study the surface oxygen species as shown in Fig. 7 a. The binding energy at about 529.0, 531.0 and 533.0eV was attributed to lattice oxygen (Oβ), the defect oxygen or the surface oxygen ions with low coordination and weakly bonded oxygen species adsorbed on the oxygen vacancies (Oα1), the adsorbed oxygen species from hydroxyl species and adsorbed water species on the surface (Oα2), respectively [45,46]. The Oα1 content calculated by Oα1/(Oα1 +Oα2 +Oβ) was listed in Table 1. The amount of Oα1 was 0.66 and 0.85 for the LBN and Ru/LBN catalysts, respectively, which suggests that more amount of the chemical adsorbed oxygen is formed on the surface of Ru/LBN. It is consistent with the results of H2-TPR and O2-TPD. It is well known that the chemical adsorbed oxygen plays an important role in NO removal and is considered as the active sites for NO dissociation [47,48]. Thus, the increase in the Oα1 ratio over the Ru/LBN is one of the favorable factors for the NO+CO reaction. Fig. 7b presents XPS of Ru3d obtained from Ru/LBN, and the peak fitting was carried out. The peaks at 281.4 and 286.1eV were attributed to 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 of the Ru3+ species [49]. It suggests that Ru3+ is only Ru species on the surface of Ru/LBN. Fig. 7c gives XPS of Ni2p for the LBN and Ru/LBN catalysts. It can be seen that two peaks at 851.0 and 863.5eV in the Ni2p3/2 and Ni2p1/2 regions were ascribed to Ni2+ [50], and the two peaks at 855.0 and 872.7eV in the Ni2p3/2 and Ni2p1/2 regions were assigned to Ni3+ [51], indicating that the Ni2+ and Ni3+ species were coexistence on the surface of catalysts. Moreover, the proportion of Ni2+ to Ni3+ for LBN was same as Ru/LBN (1.7), which indicates the addition of 0.5wt% Ru does not influence the valence state of nickel species on the surface of Ru/LBN. The NO adsorption and the reaction with CO were studied by in situ DRIFTS in order to recognize the adsorbed species on the surface of the LBN and Ru/LBN catalysts. As presented in Fig. 8 and Fig. S3 (in the Supplementary information), when the LBN catalyst was exposed to NO, three distinct bands appeared at 1523, 1348 and 1252cm−1 which were assigned to the monodentate nitrate [52,53], cis-N2O2 − [54] and bridged nitrate [53], respectively. For the Ru/LBN catalyst, some additional peaks at 1860-1760 and 1234–939cm−1 were observed besides the above three peaks, which were ascribed to Ru-NO (1860–1760cm−1) [55], bridged nitrate and nitrite (1234–939cm−1) [52]. Upon switching to CO, the intensity of band at 1252cm−1 attributed to the bridged nitrate species decreased with the increase in the flowing time of CO as presented in Fig. 8a. It means that the bridged nitrate interacts with CO on the surface of LBN. It was also found that the intensity of the band at 1526cm−1 increased and the band at 1348cm−1 disappeared with flowing time of CO. Meanwhile, two new bands appeared at 1357 and 1062cm−1 which were assigned to surface carbonates [52] and monodentate carbonate [56]. The band at 1526cm−1 which was assigned to the carboxylate was overlap with monodentate nitrate [52,53,57]. Therefore, the monodentate nitrate, cis-N2O2 − and bridged nitrate species were reduced by CO and the excess CO adsorbed on the surface of LBN catalyst. As shown in Fig. 8b, the intensity of bands at 1860–1760 and 1234–939cm−1 decreased with the increase of time and the peaks disappeared after 10min when CO was introduced into the cell. It suggests that the above species interacts with CO on the surface of Ru/LBN. The variation trend of monodentate nitrate and cis-N2O2 − on the surface of Ru/LBN was similar to that of LBN. The DRIFTS results (Fig. S3, Fig. 8b) demonstrate the formation of the active species derived from the adsorption of NO on Ru (1860–1760cm−1) and LBN (1234–939cm−1) is beneficial to the reaction between NO and CO. The CO adsorption and the reaction with NO have also been tested by in situ DRIFTS over LBN and Ru/LBN. As described in Fig. 9 and Fig. S4 (in the Supplementary information), when the LBN catalyst was exposed to CO, three bands appeared at 1513, 1368 and 1062cm−1, which were assigned to carboxylate [58], carbonates [59] and monodentate carbonate [56], respectively. For Ru/LBN, the peaks at 1526, 1347 and 1062cm−1 were observed, which were attributed to inorganic carboxylate (1526cm−1) [57] and monodentate carbonates species (1347cm−1) [57]. Compared with LBN, the new adsorption species (1526 and 1347cm−1) were observed on the surface of Ru/LBN catalyst. Upon switching to NO over LBN, the bands did not change after NO introducing for 25min, which suggests that the carboxylate (1513cm−1) and carbonates (1368cm−1) are not the active species for the CO+NO reaction in Fig. 9a. As shown in Fig. 9b, the surface of Ru/LBN was covered by inorganic carboxylate and monodentate carbonate after CO adsorbing. The intensity of the bands at 1526, 1347 and 1062cm−1 decreased with the increase in the flowing time of NO and the band at 1352cm−1 appeared which was assigned to the cis-N2O2 − species. It indicates that inorganic carboxylate and monodentate carbonate as the active species interact with NO, and the excess NO adsorbs on the surface of Ru/LBN forming the cis-N2O2 − species. DRIFTS results (Fig. S4) indicate that more active species (1526 and 1347cm−1) under the atmosphere of CO are formed on the surface of Ru/LBN catalyst compared with the LBN catalyst. Fig. 10 displays the DRIFTS of the CO+NO reaction over LBN and Ru/LBN at various temperatures. When LBN was exposed to CO and NO, eight bands appeared at 2367, 2340, 1774, 1736, 1526, 1347, 1238 and 1062cm−1, which were assigned to gas CO2 (2367 and 2340cm−1), carbonate (1774 and 1736cm−1), monodentate nitrate overlapped with carboxylate (1526cm−1), cis-N2O2 − overlapped with monodentate carbonate (1347cm−1), bridge nitrate (1238cm−1) and monodentate carbonate (1062cm−1), respectively. It can be seen that the band intensity of the adsorbed species increased with temperature from 50°C to 250°C, which was due to a large amount of species adsorbing on the surface of LBN with the temperature increasing. It was noticed that the band intensity of the adsorbed species decreased from 300°C to 350°C, which means that the nitrate species participated in the reaction with carbonate species. After 400°C, the intensities of peaks at 1774, 1736, 1526, 1347 and 1062cm−1 increased. Meanwhile, it can be seen that the intensity of gas CO2 peaks at 2367 and 2340cm−1 also increased after 400°C. Thus, combined with the results of CO-TPD (Fig. 6) and activity evaluations at 400 and 450°C (Fig. 1), the increase of the peaks intensity was attributed to the desorption of CO2 and adsorbed on the surface of catalysts, which was derived from the NO and CO reaction. As shown in Fig. 10b, the surface of Ru/LBN was covered by monodentate nitrate, carboxylate, cis-N2O2 −, monodentate carbonate and bridge nitrate. The change trend of species was similar to the LBN catalyst. It can be seen that the intensity of peak was almost same with the LBN catalyst at 250°C. However, the intensities of peaks were lower than those of the LBN catalyst at 300 and 350°C, which suggests that the reaction of NO and CO over Ru/LBN occur much more easily than LBN. Furthermore, the peak intensity was also lower at 400 and 450°C compared with LBN, which demonstrates that the generated species (CO2) adsorbed on the surface of Ru/LBN catalyst, and parts of them desorbed at 400 and 450°C. It also illuminates that the catalytic activity of Ru/LBN for NO and CO reaction is higher than that of LBN. 4 Discussion As described in Fig. 1, Fig. S2 and Fig. 10, the catalytic activity of Ru/LBN for the NO+CO reaction was much higher than that of LBN. Moreover, Ru/LBN catalyst showed stable catalytic activity. It is mainly attributed to the Ru species and the surface structure change of LBN derived from the interaction between Ru and LBN. The results of XPS (Fig. 7) confirm the existence of Ru3+ species on the surface of Ru/LBN, which was considered as an active site for the NO+CO reaction [60]. The Benco’s report confirmed the hypothesis [61]. They used DFT to calculate the activation energy of NOx molecule over the Ru3+ species (cationic oxo-particles (Ru-O+)). From the adsorption energy, the reaction heat of the dissociation of the NOx molecule and the activation energy, the Ru3+ species (Ru-O+ particle) exhibits high activity for the activation of the NOx molecule [56]. In addition, the ratio of Oα1 (defect oxygen or the surface oxygen ions with low coordination and weakly bonded oxygen) to total oxygen species (Oα1/(Oα1 +Oα2 +Oβ)) is 0.66 and 0.85 for LBN and Ru/LBN catalysts from the XPS of O1s (Table 1), respectively, which suggests that much more amount of the chemical adsorbed oxygen is formed on the surface of Ru/LBN compared with that of LBN. This is consistent with the results of H2-TPR (Fig. 3) and O2-TPD (Fig. 4). It is well known that the chemical adsorbed oxygen plays an important role in NO removal and is also considered as the active site for NO dissociation. Thus, the chemical adsorbed oxygen on the oxygen vacancy of Ru/LBN was one of the favorable factors for NO and CO reaction. The reaction process of NO+CO was also concluded for Ru/LBN catalyst. When Ru/LBN was exposed to CO and NO, gas molecules adsorbed on the active sites of catalyst. Owing to NO unpaired electron, competitive adsorption of it was stronger than CO molecule [62]. The key step of NO+CO reaction was dissociation of NO [63] that the NO bond was to fracture and form N and O, which occurred easily on the oxygen vacancy and Ru species [64,65]. Two N radicals diffuse on the surface of catalyst and recombine into the gas-phase nitrogen. It also could interact with another NO to form N2O on the surface of catalyst and desorbed. CO adsorbed on the active sites could react with the O derived from the dissociation of NO to generate CO2. In addition, the change of the surface adsorption property is also an important factor on improving the activity of the NO+CO reaction over Ru/LBN. The results of NO-TPD (Fig. 5) and CO-TPD (Fig. 6) suggest that there are more adsorption sites of NO and CO on the surface of Ru/LBN than on LBN. Moreover, the adsorption amounts of NO and CO increase significantly for the Ru/LBN catalyst. Furthermore, there is a large amount of N2O and CO2 in the process of NO-TPD (Fig. 5d) and CO-TPD (Fig. 6d), respectively, corresponding the amount of NO and CO desorption was much smaller. This means that it is easy to activate for NO and CO on the surface of Ru/LBN catalyst, which was benefit to the NO+CO reaction (Fig. 1). The DRIFTS (Fig. S3, S4, 8 and 9) also confirm above results. In DRIFTS, some additional peaks including bridged nitrate and nitrite (1234–939cm−1), inorganic carboxylate (1526cm−1) and monodentate carbonate (1347cm−1) are formed on the surface of Ru/LBN catalyst under the atmosphere of NO or CO compared with LBN. Above results should be attributed to the change of the surface properties of Ru/LBN catalyst derived from the interaction between Ru and LBN, which is also reflected by the H2-TPR (Fig. 3), O2-TPD (Fig. 4). In Figs. 8 and 9, those adsorbed species of NO and CO disappeared quickly after introducing CO or NO, respectively. Thus, it is identified that bridged nitrate and nitrite (1234–939cm−1), inorganic carboxylate (1526cm−1) and monodentate carbonate (1347cm−1) are active species for the NO+CO reaction. So the improvement of CO and NO adsorption capacity and the formation of more active species (bridged nitrate and nitrite (1234–939cm−1), inorganic carboxylate (1526cm−1) and monodentate carbonate (1347cm−1)) were also the key reasons for the excellent catalytic property of Ru/LBN. On the whole, the Ru3+ species is an effective active site for the NO and CO reaction. The interaction between Ru and LBN leads to the surface structure change of LBN which improves the reducibility, the amount of chemical adsorption oxygen, the mobility of lattice oxygen, the ability of CO and NO adsorption. Therefore, the catalytic activity of Ru/LBN is much higher than that of LBN for the NO+CO reaction. 5 Conclusions LBN and Ru/LBN perovskite-like catalysts were prepared and applied to the NO+CO reaction. The Ru/LBN catalyst exhibited much higher activity than LBN. It was attributed to existence of the Ru3+ species and the surface structure change of Ru/LBN due to the interaction between Ru and LBN, which leaded to enhancing the mobility of the lattice oxygen and the reducibility, increasing the amount of the surface oxygen species and the amount of CO and NO adsorbed on the surface of Ru/LBN. In addition, in situ DRIFTS revealed that some new adsorbed species of NO and CO including inorganic carboxylate (1526cm−1), monodentate carbonate (1347cm−1), Ru-NO (1860–1760cm−1), bridged nitrate and nitrite (1234–919cm−1) were formed on the surface of Ru/LBN after NO and CO adsorbing compared with LBN, which is the high activity species for the NO+CO reaction. coredata.dc:description: In this paper, the activity of La1.6Ba0.4NiO4 (LBN) and Ru/La1.6Ba0.4NiO4 (Ru/LBN) perovskite-like catalysts was investigated for NO+CO reaction. Meanwhile, Ru/LBN exhibited much higher activity than LBN. The catalysts were fully characterized by means of XRD, elemental analysis, N2-physisorption, H2-TPR, XPS, O2-TPD, NO-TPD and CO-TPD. These results demonstrated that the excellent catalytic performance of Ru/LBN catalyst was associated with the strong interaction between Ru and LBN, leading to enhancing reducibility and mobility of oxygen species and increasing the amount of the surface adsorbed oxygen. In addition, the amount of adsorbed CO and NO increased largely for Ru/LBN. And Ru3+ species on the surface of Ru/LBN was considered as an effective active site for NO+CO reaction. In-situ DRIFTS was used for studying the relationship between catalytic activity and NO, CO adsorption ability, species and sites. The results indicated that the new active species were formed on the surface of Ru/LBN compared with LBN including inorganic carboxylate, monodentate carbonate, Ru-NO, bridged nitrate and nitrite.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic activity of Ru/La1.6Ba0.4NiO4 perovskite-like catalyst for NO+CO reaction: Interaction between Ru and La1.6Ba0.4NiO4
